title: 104_hr3998
content: The "Citizen Debt Reduction Contribution Act" includes provisions for donating income tax refunds, social security benefits, military retirement benefits, and veterans' disability compensation to reduce the Federal deficit. The Act also addresses the budgetary treatment of savings resulting from these donations. The Congress emphasizes that budget savings from the Act should reduce Government spending. A new part in the Internal Revenue Code allows taxpayers to designate income tax overpayments to reduce public debt. Taxpayers can designate a portion of their tax overpayment to reduce the public debt of the United States. This designation must be made at the time of filing the tax return and in the manner prescribed by the Secretary. The designated amount is treated as a refund to the taxpayer. Taxpayers can designate a portion of their tax overpayment to reduce the public debt of the United States. The designated amount is treated as a refund to the taxpayer and as a contribution to the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for transferring these designated amounts to a special account for deficit reduction. Part IX. Designation of income tax overpayments to reduce public debt. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 4. Donation of Social Security benefits to reduce the federal deficit. Section 201(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow recipients of monthly insurance benefits to elect to transfer a portion of their benefits to the general fund of the Treasury as a gift. The Managing Trustee is authorized to accept gifts under section 3113 of title 31, United States Code for reducing the public debt. Amounts subject to this election are not taxable under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No deductions are allowed for amounts not included in gross income. SEC. 5. Donation of military retirement benefits for reducing the federal deficit. The new section added to Chapter 71 of title 10, United States Code, allows members or former members of the armed forces to donate a portion of their retired or retainer pay to the Treasury to reduce the public debt. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to accept these donations. The Secretary of the Treasury can accept donations under section 3113 of title 31 to reduce the public debt. Amounts under this section are not taxable under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Donations can be made to reduce the public debt and veterans' disability compensation can be donated to reduce the federal deficit. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can establish a program for veterans to donate a portion of their compensation to reduce the public debt. The Secretary of the Treasury can accept these donations as gifts. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can establish a program for veterans to donate a portion of their compensation to reduce the public debt. The amount transferred to the Secretary under this section is considered a gift under section 3113 of title 31. Amounts subject to this election are not taxable under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No deductions are allowed for amounts not included in gross income. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. The enactment of this Act allows veterans to donate a portion of their compensation to reduce the public debt. Savings resulting from this Act will not be considered for budget estimates under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
